qas.question: What molecular form is found in the interstellar medium?

answers.text: ionization of molecular hydrogen from cosmic rays

qas.question: On what planet can you find  protonated molecular hydrogen?
In what way can Neutral triatomic hydrogen exist?

context:
A molecular form called <a0_0>protonated molecular hydrogen<a0_0/> (H+
3) is found in the interstellar medium, where it is generated by <a1_0>ionization of molecular hydrogen from cosmic rays<a1_0/>. This charged ion has also been observed in the upper atmosphere of the planet <a2_0>Jupiter<a2_0/>. The ion is relatively stable in the environment of outer space due to the low temperature and density. H+
3 is one of the most abundant ions in the Universe, and it plays a notable role in the chemistry of the interstellar medium. Neutral triatomic hydrogen H3 can only exist in an <a3_0>excited form<a3_0/> and is unstable. By contrast, the positive hydrogen molecular ion (H+
2) is a rare molecule in the universe.
